options.option_text: The body/payload in an HTTP request is mandatory
The “Content-Length” header indicates the size of the request body in bytes
User diagnosis and recovery from errors

questions.question_text_1: A mobile client starts from and is cruising away continuously at 60 kmph from the network tower whose network range is 40 km and bandwidth is 120 Mbps. How much data (in Gigabytes) will be consumed by the client who is continuously using the entire bandwidth before completely moving out of the network?  [Take 1 Byte = 8 bits, 1 KB = 1000 Bytes, 1 MB = 1000 Kilobytes and so on.]  [Consider the speed of light in air to be 3 x 108 m/sec.]
question_texts: A mobile client starts from and is cruising away continuously at 60 kmph from the network tower whose network range is 40 km and bandwidth is 120 Mbps. questions.question_text_1: What is the correct sequence of working of Client-Server Architecture.  a. The client asks for the IP address for the particular server from the Domain Name system. b. To that IP address, the client sends the request to the particular server with that port number that is specified to the particular application and then server responds c. The DNS server responds with the IP address. d. The response message is received by the client and based on that port number, the response packet is consumed by the application to which it belongs.

The DNS server responds with the IP address. d. The response message is received by the client and based on that port number, the response packet is consumed by the application to which it belongs.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **HTTP Protocol**
- **Concepts**: HTTP headers, request body, Content-Type, Content-Length.
- **Principles**: HTTP headers are not case-sensitive, the request body is not mandatory, Content-Length indicates the size of the request body in bytes.

#### 2. **Matrices and Determinants**
- **Concepts**: Square matrices, binary equivalents, Least Significant Bits (LSB).
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{Determinant of a 2x2 matrix } A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \text{ is } ad - bc.
  \]
  For larger matrices, use the Laplace expansion or other methods.

#### 3. **Usability Heuristics**
- **Concepts**: Error prevention, visibility of system status, user control and freedom, user diagnosis and recovery from errors.
- **Principles**: Immediate feedback for errors, clear error messages, user-friendly design.

#### 4. **URL Components**
- **Concepts**: Protocol, domain, sub-domain, path.
- **Principles**: Understanding the structure of URLs and their components.

#### 5. **Character Encoding and Disk Size**
- **Concepts**: Character sets, fixed encoding, disk size calculations.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{Number of characters} = \frac{\text{Disk size in bytes}}{\text{Size of each character in bytes}}.
  \]

#### 6. **Network Bandwidth and Data Consumption**
- **Concepts**: Bandwidth, network range, data consumption.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{Data consumed} = \text{Bandwidth} \times \text{Time}.
  \]
  \[
  \text{Time} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Speed}}.
  \]

#### 7. **Python String Templates**
- **Concepts**: String templates, substitution, error handling.
- **Principles**: Using Python's `Template` class for string substitution.

#### 8. **CSS Specificity**
- **Concepts**: Element selectors, ID selectors, class selectors, specificity.
- **Principles**: ID selectors have higher specificity than class selectors, which have higher specificity than element selectors.

#### 9. **Client-Server Architecture**
- **Concepts**: IP addresses, DNS, request-response cycle.
- **Principles**: The sequence of steps in client-server communication.

#### 10. **HTML and CSS Rendering**
- **Concepts**: HTML elements, CSS styles, rendering.
- **Principles**: How browsers apply styles based on specificity and inheritance.

#### 11. **Jinja2 Templating**
- **Concepts**: Template rendering, variable substitution, loops.
- **Principles**: Using Jinja2 for dynamic content generation.

#### 12. **Flask Application**
- **Concepts**: Flask routes, static files, command-line arguments.
- **Principles**: Handling static files and dynamic routes in Flask.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[HTTP Protocol] --> B[HTTP Headers]
    A --> C[Request Body]
    A --> D[Content-Type]
    A --> E[Content-Length]

    F[Matrices and Determinants] --> G[Square Matrices]
    F --> H[Binary Equivalents]
    F --> I[Least Significant Bits]

    J[Usability Heuristics] --> K[Error Prevention]
    J --> L[Visibility of System Status]
    J --> M[User Control and Freedom]
    J --> N[User Diagnosis and Recovery]

    O[URL Components] --> P[Protocol]
    O --> Q[Domain]
    O --> R[Sub-Domain]
    O --> S[Path]

    T[Character Encoding] --> U[Character Sets]
    T --> V[Fixed Encoding]
    T --> W[Disk Size Calculations]

    X[Network Bandwidth] --> Y[Bandwidth]
    X --> Z[Network Range]
    X --> AA[Data Consumption]

    AB[Python String Templates] --> AC[String Templates]
    AB --> AD[Substitution]
    AB --> AE[Error Handling]

    AF[CSS Specificity] --> AG[Element Selectors]
    AF --> AH[ID Selectors]
    AF --> AI[Class Selectors]
    AF --> AJ[Specificity]

    AK[Client-Server Architecture] --> AL[IP Addresses]
    AK --> AM[DNS]
    AK --> AN[Request-Response Cycle]

    AO[HTML and CSS Rendering] --> AP[HTML Elements]
    AO --> AQ[CSS Styles]
    AO --> AR[Rendering]

    AS[Jinja2 Templating] --> AT[Template Rendering]
    AS --> AU[Variable Substitution]
    AS --> AV[Loops]

    AW[Flask Application] --> AX[Flask Routes]
    AW --> AY[Static Files]
    AW --> AZ[Command-Line Arguments]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics covered in the exam. Each node represents a core topic, and the edges represent the relationships or subtopics within each core topic.
